title: [GCP] Fix unbounded return value
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This is a bug in GCP node_provider, where an unnecessary variable is returned, which is not defined in one code path.

Reference: https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/547dd8c125b0e2007b1fb8960b514bd2c89e1963/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/gcp/node_provider.py#L183-L205

~~The parallel termination is adopted from: https://github.com/ray-project/ray/commit/46fc66390cb136a52afd6d70808f7c01eb31deb0~~

We revert the adoption of the parallel termination as that implementation is buggy with the following repro:
1. `sky launch -c test --cloud gcp --cpus 2 --num-nodes 8`
2. `sky stop test`, the following error shows up:
```
malloc(): unsorted double linked list corrupted
```


<!-- Describe the tests ran -->

title: [Storage] when storage created outside of sky has identical name to storage created with sky
body: When the name of storage created with `sky` already existed under the user's account and has been created outside of sky, the storage gets synced with local directory and get mounted to remote node even though it is not a storage created through `sky`. Also, this does not get marked in `state.db`, and therefore, does not appear when `sky storage ls` is ran. As the user may have created the storage for different purpose in the past, this behavior can cause unexpected result. We may need some gaurding before creating the storage to check if the user already has the identical bucket name created outside of sky.

title: Fix redundant task creation that leads to redundant attempt to create storage
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR closes #2128 

Currently, when non-pipeline Task yaml is submitted, `_make_task_or_dag_from_entrypoint_with_overrides` runs `Task.from_yaml_config()` twice from `dag_utils.load_chain_dag_from_yaml()` and `sky.Task.from_yaml(entrypoint)`. This results to an attempt to create the storages defined in the yaml twice. This fix replaces the call to `Task.from_yaml` with `dag.tasks[0]` to eliminate the redundant function call.


Tested (run the relevant ones):
- [x] Manual test sky launch task.yaml, which has storages defined
- [x] pytest tests/test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials

title: Passing secrets to remote machine
body:
Hi there,
Was wondering what the best practices are for passing secrets/keys to a worker provisioned with skypilot. 
Currently, I'm using skypilot to run a docker image. 

I saw this example in your docs for wandb creds:
```
file_mounts:
  ~/.netrc: ~/.netrc
  ```
  
For docker, I could do the same file_mount for a .env file and then mount the .env to the docker container.  

Just wanted to know if this is the best way to manage secrets with skypilot, and how secure this approach would be. 
Best,
Erwann

title: [Storage] GCS syncing fails when the src directory contains courrupted symlink
body:
User reported that gcs sync errors out when the src directory contains dangling symlink.

The command we run to sync the contents from local directory to cloud storage for s3 is `aws s3 sync` and `gsutil rsync -r` for gcs. When the local directory being synced contains a dangling symlink(the file/dir it points to does not exist anymore), `gsutil rsync -r` errors out while `aws s3 sync` ignores this and move on and continues to sync other file/dir. 

Output for the commands when the dir contains dangling symlink:
`aws s3 sync`:
```
aws s3 sync . s3://doyoung-test
warning: Skipping file /path/to/dangling/symlink. File does not exist.
```

`gsutil rsync -r`:
```
gsutil rsync -r . gs://doyoung-test

WARNING: gsutil rsync uses hashes when modification time is not available at
both the source and destination. Your crcmod installation isn't using the
module's C extension, so checksumming will run very slowly. If this is your
first rsync since updating gsutil, this rsync can take significantly longer than
usual. For help installing the extension, please see "gsutil help crcmod".

Building synchronization state...
Caught non-retryable exception while listing file://.: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/path/to/dangling/symlink'
CommandException: Caught non-retryable exception - aborting rsync
```

We need to error-handle dangling symlink when syncing attempted to GCS. Perhaps, gently display an error message and move on to sync rest of the files in the directory rather than erroring out.

title: API/YAML: Support using env vars to define file_mounts.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

```
# Use env vars in the "name" (bucket name) and "source" (local dir/file to
# upload) fields.
#
# Both syntaxes work: ${MY_BUCKET} and $MY_BUCKET.
file_mounts:
  /mydir:
    name: ${MY_BUCKET}  # Name of the bucket.
    store: gcs
    mode: MOUNT

  /another-dir:
    name: ${MY_BUCKET}-2
    source: ["~/${MY_LOCAL_PATH}"]
    store: gcs
    mode: MOUNT
```
Overriding with `sky launch --env` works too.

Also fixes `sky launch` parsing errors: 
- Do not load YAML twice (which creates storage twice)
- Properly load empty / name-only YAMLs

Fixes #2093.

title: [Spot, doc] Update transformer repository version from bert_qa example
body:
This PR resolves #2127 

Currently, bert_qa example uses v4.18.0 [transformer repository](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers) from Huggingface. And this version contains a symlink that is dangling. The symlink set for directory transformers/examples/legacy/seq2seq/test_data/test_data does not exist in v4.18.0. This corrupted symlink was [recently fixed](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/pull/22876). Hence, I'm updating the example doc to inform users to `git clone` the recent version, v4.30.1, of the transformer repo.
 
v4.18.0 will not have an issue when using S3 storage to store `workdir`, since `aws s3 sync` ignores such courrpted symlink and moves on with syncing. But the user with error in #2127 has set GCS to be the `workdir` storage, and `gsutil rsync -r` does not ignore corrupted symlink and fails the command.


Tested (run the relevant ones):
- [x] Test workdir sync with newest version of transformer repo

title: INIT/STARTING Status Stuck
body: When trying to replicate the Vicuna example, I encountered two separate bugs that both relate to being stuck at a status INIT/STARTING. At first, my spot jobs were stuck in the STARTING status: After stopping those jobs, and trying to start more, my spot controller was stuck at the INIT status: I SSH'ed into the spot controller, and viewed the provision.log, and saw this error: `Exception: {'errors': [{'code': 'QUOTA_EXCEEDED', 'message': "Quota 'NVIDIA_A100_80GB_GPUS' exceeded. Limit: 0.0 in region us-east5.", 'errorDetails': [{'quotaInfo': {'metricName': 'compute.googleapis.com/nvidia_a100_80gb_gpus', 'limitName': 'NVIDIA-A100-80GB-GPUS-per-project-region', 'dimensions': {'region': 'us-east5'}, 'limit': 0}}]}]}` I believe SkyPilot was endlessly trying to use every single region available, and cycling through different regions, but none had the necessary quota for the job I was trying to run, and so it was stuck in the status INIT/STARTING. Flagging because I believe a possible fix to avoid future user confusion would be to timeout after a certain amount of time or number of attempts, and some sort of feedback should be given to the user to increase their quota.

title: [Storage] Fix transient gsutil multiprocessing errors
body:
Uploading many files using gsutil (e.g., in `test_bucket_bulk_deletion`) transiently fails on macos. This is a known issue with gsutil and multiprocessing on macos, as stated in their warning at the start of every transfer:

```
Building synchronization state...
   
If you experience problems with multiprocessing on MacOS, they might be related to https://bugs.python.org/issue33725. You can disable multiprocessing by editing your .boto config or by adding the following flag to your command: `-o "GSUtil:parallel_process_count=1"`. Note that multithreading is still available even if you disable multiprocessing.
```

Also documented [here](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil/issues/464) and [here](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil/issues/1053).

This PR adds `GSUtil:parallel_process_count=1` to make `gsutil -m` operations single process (but still multi-threaded).

Ran some benchmarks to compare perf. Adds a small penalty (~6%), but makes gsutil reliable. Smoke tests (esp. `test_bucket_bulk_deletion`) reliably passes now.
```
for i in {1..100}; do dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile${i}.tmp bs=1M count=1; done # 100 1mb files
mkdir -p folder{{000..255}} # 256 small dirs
touch folder{{000..255}}/test.txt # 256 small files inside each dir
touch test{{000..255}}.txt # 256 small files

gsutil mb gs://romilb-bench
time gsutil -m rsync . gs://romilb-bench    
gsutil rm -r gs://romilb-bench

gsutil mb gs://romilb-bench
time gsutil -m -o "GSUtil:parallel_process_count=1" rsync . gs://romilb-bench    
gsutil rm -r gs://romilb-bench

# Results:
# gsutil -m rsync - 1:17.17 # Average over 4 runs, out of which 1 failed because of connection refused error
# gsutil -m -o "GSUtil:parallel_process_count=1" rsync -  1:22.26 total # Average over 3 runs
```

title: Propagating the remote job exit code to the local process
body:
Exploring the idea of using SkyPilot in an automated CI pipeline made me realize that (afaik) there isn't a built-in way to propagate the remote job exit code to the local process. This is needed if we want a CI pipeline to fail whenever the remote job failed.

I developed a quick hack, essentially parsing the second to last line of the last job's logs, it looks like this:

```yaml
script:
    - sky launch -i 2 -y -c e2e-test-gpu tests/gpu-launcher/launch-gpu-tests.yml
    - if [[ $(sky logs e2e-test-gpu | tail -n 2 | head -n 1) == ERROR* ]]; then exit 1; else exit 0; fi
```

There is probably a better (built-in) way of doing this, perhaps by adding an optional `--propagate-exit-code` flag to the `sky launch` command, what do you think?

The problem causing the two issues is that we hardcoded the application default key path in our code to find the credentials. However, the user may specify the key in the environment variable `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS`

We now first check the env var to look for the credential file, if the env var does not exist, we will use the default path (same as the gcloud's behavior).

title: Auto-shutdown is not triggered when using sky launch from a CI server
body:
A small weird and low priority issue that I discovered during my testing of the features proposed in #2109 is that the auto-shutdown does not seem to work when set from a CI runner. I cannot really explain this yet, and did not investigate it further because using `sky stop` at the end of the job works well for me in this case. Quickly looking at the logs does not reveal anything suspicious. I don't know if this is an artefact of our environment or if there is something deeper happening from SkyPilot.

To replicate, here is a example Gitlab CI job configuration:

```yaml
GPU tests:
  image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
  stage: Test
  before_script:
    - apt-get install rsync -y
    - pip install --upgrade pip
    - pip install skypilot[gcp]
    - echo $GPU_TESTING_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_KEY > gpu-testing-service-account-key.json
    - export GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS="gpu-testing-service-account-key.json"
    - gcloud auth activate-service-account --key-file gpu-testing-service-account-key.json 
    - gcloud config set project $GCP_PROJECT_ID
    # Hack to bypass SkyPilot hardcoded verification
    # See https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/2109
    - touch ~/.config/gcloud/application_default_credentials.json
  script:
    - sky launch -i 5 -y -c e2e-test-gpu tests/gpu-launcher/launch-gpu-tests.yml
```

The job exits gracefully, but the machine is not stopped even after waiting for more than 30 minutes.

If you fail to replicate and if you need me to investigate something in particular related to this issue, don't hesitate to reach out!

title: Logging in to GCP using a service account
body:
I was thinking about a potential interesting use case for SkyPilot in my team: being able to automatically launch our GPU test suite in CI. This is something we struggled with for quite some time, and I did not find any good solution for this. We recently introduced SkyPilot into our workflow and currently, SkyPilot already helps us launch these tests from a local development machine. But going one step further, it would be fantastic if launching the test suite could be fully automated in our CI pipeline.

For some context, we are using GCP and a Gitlab self-managed instance.

My idea was to interact with the GCP project in a CI runner through a service account, I tried to prototype a working solution, here is what I did:
- creating a dedicated machine called `e2e-test-gpu` in our GCP project using SkyPilot
- creating a service account with a minimal set of permissions as discussed in #2100 and exported a JSON service account key
- adding the key in a `$GPU_TESTING_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_KEY` Variable in Gitlab CI
- creating a `launch-gpu-tests.yml` SkyPilot configuration with a command to launch our GPU test suite
- adding the following job in our `.gitlab-ci.yml`:

```yaml
GPU tests:
  image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
  stage: Test
  before_script:
    - pip install --upgrade pip
    - pip install skypilot[gcp]
  script:
    - echo $GPU_TESTING_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_KEY > gpu-testing-service-account-key.json
    - export GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS="gpu-testing-service-account-key.json"
    - gcloud auth activate-service-account --key-file gpu-testing-service-account-key.json 
    - gcloud config set project $GCP_PROJECT_ID
    - sky check
    - sky launch -i 1 -c e2e-test-gpu tests/gpu-launcher/launch-gpu-tests.yml
```

In the CI runner, the command `sky check` warns that it failed to connect to GCP:

```
  GCP: disabled          
    Reason: GCP tools are not installed or credentials are not set. Run the following commands:
      $ pip install google-api-python-client
      $ conda install -c conda-forge google-cloud-sdk -y
      $ gcloud init
      $ gcloud auth application-default login
    For more info: https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started/installation.html
```

The dependencies `google-cloud-sdk` and `google-api-python-client` are correctly installed, so it seems that it's the authentification part that caused the failure. My guess is that SkyPilot necessarily expects a user to be logged in, but for automated workflows we probably want to use a service account instead. Is there a technical limitation preventing such a use case, and if not is it a feature of interest to you? Such a feature would unlock interesting use cases.

EDIT: A quick skimming through the code reveals that the file `~/.config/gcloud/application_default_credentials.json` is explicitly checked for existence on [this line](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/d6c2b7a0748b2e1b935a6bace2e3f76f3f600f79/sky/clouds/gcp.py#L488) and may be the culprit here. This file is a user credential file and does not exist when logged through a service account. Instead, the standard practice is to set the `$GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS` environment variable to the key's path, so we can check if this variable is set before using the user credential.

title: [Spot] Event callback for adding notification
body: Issue #2000: A user would like to have a customizable event callback for the spot job, so that they can implement some notification when the spot job status changes. Example: ``` event_callback: send_slack_message $JOB_ID $JOB_STATUS ``` Allows the controller to execute a customizable bash script when the spot status changes. Example: Register a Slack message web hook from [here](https://api.slack.com/apps?new_app=1). ``` event_callback: | echo 'this is an event callback script' curl -X POST -H 'Content-type: application/json' --data "{\"text\":\"JOB_ID: $SKYPILOT_JOB_ID, JOB_STATUS: $JOB_STATUS\"}" https://hooks.slack.com/services/... ``` The user will receive a Slack notification when the spot status changes. title: [k8s] Kubernetes support
body:
Adds Kubernetes support to SkyPilot. Still largely a WIP, expect rough edges and please provide feedback :)

To try out, create a Kubernetes cluster (either locally with Kind or some hosted service like GKE, instructions [here](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/k8s_cloud/tests/kubernetes/README.md#running-a-local-development-cluster)), make sure ports 30000-32767 are accessible, and place the kubeconfig in `~/.kube/config` and run `sky check`.

Current status, TODOs, and roadmap can be found in this [doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IrrkbtkX74gx1VHlPLjB9c_CTpuE4VZiB-QCXPehzqY/edit#bookmark=id.jh816bcfn0is).

Also adds two new CLI commands:
* `sky local up` create a local kubernetes cluster to run tasks locally. Requires docker and kind installed.
* `sky local down` tears down the local cluster.

**What's not supported in this PR:**
* Multi-node
* GPU support
* Supporting multiple Kubernetes clusters
* Docs (both for admins and users)
* Stopping clusters
* ... 

```
(base) ➜  ~ SKYPILOT_DEBUG=0 sky launch --cpus 8+
== Optimizer ==
Target: minimizing cost
Estimated cost: $0.0 / hour

Considered resources (1 node):
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 CLOUD        INSTANCE          vCPUs   Mem(GB)   ACCELERATORS   REGION/ZONE   COST ($)   CHOSEN
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Kubernetes   8vCPU-8GB         8       8         -              kubernetes    0.00          ✔
 AWS          m6i.2xlarge       8       32        -              us-east-1     0.38
 Azure        Standard_D8s_v5   8       32        -              eastus        0.38
 IBM          bx2-8x32          8       32        -              us-east       0.38
 GCP          n2-standard-8     8       32        -              us-central1   0.39
 Lambda       gpu_1x_a10        30      200       A10:1          us-east-1     0.60
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

title: Use environment variable to define file mount
body:
Hi and thanks for this great project !

I am in a situation where I would like to mount some directory in a bucket which changes based on the value of an environment variable. I am unsure how to do this with SkyPilot as defining a file mount would typically require that I specify the corresponding URL in my task YAML file beforehand.

Put simply I'd like to do
```yaml
file_mounts:
  /some/folder:
    source: $URL_IN_MY_ENVVAR
    mode: MOUNT
```

And be able to set `URL_IN_MY_ENVVAR ` at runtime.
Am I missing something or would it be a feature that may be of interest?

<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR is to fix the TODO action item for OCI disk_tier support. Detail test is performanced to map the skypiot disk_tier value to OCI VPU value:

disk_tier value in skypilot:
    low: 500 IOPS; read 20MB/s; write 40 MB/s
    medium: 3000 IOPS; read 220 MB/s; write 200 MB/s
    high: 6000 IOPS; 340 MB/s; write 250 MB/s

title: [Core] Resource leakage for sky down if a multi-node cluster is partially stopped
body:
If a multi-node cluster is partially stopped (during autostop or manually stop the worker node), i.e. the cluster is in INIT state, our `backend.teardown` function will fail to terminate the stopped nodes, as we are using `ray down` to terminate the cluster, and ray ignores the stopped nodes.
Related code path: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/b9626015fd4cd01ab29d4354ba38c5ff17884e3d/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L3367-L3369

To reproduce:
1. `sky launch -c min --cloud gcp --num-nodes 2 --cpus 2`
2. Manually stop the worker node.
3. `sky down min`

After that, the head node will be terminated, but the worker node is still in STOPPED state.

One possible solution is to only use our own cloud cli-based termination (should be careful: may need to kill the head node first to avoid ray autoscaler restarting some of the worker nodes, causing leakage).

title: [Question] Strong Minimal Cloud Permissions with GCP
body:
Hi, according to [the documentation](https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cloud-setup/cloud-permissions.html#gcp) the following roles must be granted to each account using SkyPilot:
```
roles/browser
roles/compute.admin
roles/iam.serviceAccountAdmin
roles/iam.serviceAccountUser
roles/serviceusage.serviceUsageConsumer
roles/storage.admin
```

Some of these roles are quiet strong (most notably `iam.serviceAccountAdmin`), I'm curious about the rationale behind these requirements. My issue with it is the following: our GCP project is shared between multiple developers, each developer is granted a fine-grained permission set depending on what is needed. We want to assess if it's possible for all developers to use SkyPilot without granting excessive additional permissions.

Initially I thought that `roles/iam.serviceAccountAdmin` was only needed once, to create the SkyPilot service account, and that users can all start and use VMs using this existing service account. However it appears that `roles/iam.serviceAccountAdmin` is also needed when using `sky down`. Is it really necessary? If so, what is the recommended usage of SkyPilot for shared projects like ours? According to [the GCP documentation](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/understanding-roles?hl=fr#service-accounts-roles), the role `roles/iam.serviceAccountAdmin` bundles the following autorisations:
```
iam.serviceAccounts.create
iam.serviceAccounts.delete
iam.serviceAccounts.disable
iam.serviceAccounts.enable
iam.serviceAccounts.get
iam.serviceAccounts.getIamPolicy
iam.serviceAccounts.list
iam.serviceAccounts.setIamPolicy
iam.serviceAccounts.undelete
iam.serviceAccounts.update
resourcemanager.projects.get
resourcemanager.projects.list
```

Could you clarify which specific permissions are required for regular users to use SkyPilot?

Thank you very much. We're excited to integrate SkyPilot into our workflow!

title: Speed up refresh: delay the slower `ray status` call & use cached IPs.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

I noticed that `status -r` is taking way too long. With some investigation with @Michaelvll, this PR Implemented two optimizations:
- delay the slower `ray status` call 
- use cached IPs

All tests below are 1-node on-demand GCP clusters. These are all "normal" case where the runtime on the cluster did not become problematic.


- TODO: we should keep speeding up refresh in the future.
  - [ ] identified `handle.external_ips(use_cached_ips=False) -> ray get head-ip/worker-ips` is too slow; replace with NodeProvider calls or cloud CLI/SDK calls?


Results:

**do `ray status` last + use_cached_ips=True**

STOPPED -> STOPPED
- before: 31s
- now: 3.7s

UP, autostop not set -> UP  
- before: 8.9s
- now: 7.1s

UP, autostopped -> STOPPED
- before: 22.2s
- now: 4.2s

UP, autostop set -> UP
- before: 7.6s
- now: 7.3s

INIT -> INIT
- before: 25.7s
- now: 22.3s

**(if we do the first optimization only) do `ray status` last** 

STOPPED -> STOPPED
- before: 31s
- now: 3.9s

UP, autostop not set -> UP  
- before: 8.9s
- now: 10.9s

UP, autostopped -> STOPPED
- before: 22.2s
- now: 6s

UP, autostop set -> UP
- before: 7.6s
- now: 11.4s

INIT -> INIT
- before: 25.7s
- now: 22.4s

title: [Core] Autoscaler create_node one by one?
body:
Try this case:
I have a sky "STOPPED" cluster like this: 
- 1 head node (state STOPPED) 
- 2 worker nodes (One of workers is "STOPPED", the other is actually in "RUNNING" state)

Then I run "sky start mycluster", it actions as following:
1. Startup head node success;
2. Call create_node for worker nodes. **Here it should pass in the parameter count = 2, why it is 1?**
3. In create_node function, it founds 1 running node, so no need to create new node.
4. Thus the second worker node will never be UP because it can find a running node everytime calling the create_node.

title: [OCI] Support Oracle Object Storage
body: Support OCI Object Storage as a sky storage layer. So that OCI storage bucket can be mounted to the provisioned compute instance and accessed directly as local.

title: [Spot] RESOURCES column does not show resource request correctly
body:
> RESOURCES: it seems to show accelerators correctly (e.g., 1x [T4:1]), but if a task instead has cpus: 2+, it shows 1x [CPU:0.5]

This seems to be an existing problem that happens for non-pipeline spot jobs as well. I am leaning toward to fixing it in another future PR. Wdyt?

_Originally posted by @Michaelvll in https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1982#issuecomment-1585969257_

title: [OCI fix] Nodes are not reusable if launch config changed
body:
This is a corner case. If start an existing cluster, but the backed nodes (or part of them) now have different ray-launch-config tag   value with the tags parameter in the create_node interface, the ray autoscaler will not accept those nodes as reusable. It will then stop those nodes, which are recognized by the OCI node provider as reusable, and then start new nodes instead. This is not expected behavior. We expect the nodes in the same cluster can be reused even if the ray-launch-config tag is different. 

Tested (run the relevant ones):

title: [OCI] Support configurable boot volume size (disk_size) and performance (disk_tier)
body:
This is an enhancement for OCI. 

disk_size: Before this PR, the instances created by sky/ray were always with default boot volume size (~50G). This enhancement aims to support customizable boot volume size (max up to 32T), so that those tasks that needs to load large dataset or tasks that have large amount of outputs can be supported by OCI. We reuse the disk_size parameter in the task yaml for this impl.

disk_tier: OCI supports specify volume performance (vpu) for boot volume. SkyPilot (>0.25) has disk_tier (low, medium, high) parameter defined for specifying disk performance. So here OCI reuse the disk_tier parameter to serve different boot volume performance requirements.

Tested (run the relevant ones):
1. sky launch cpu task
2. sky launch gpu task

title: [Core] Fix log buffering issue
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Fixes #2065.

The original selectors implementation introduces buffer. We changed it to threading based implementation and it now fixes the buffering problem. Tried asyncio, but since the log_lib can be used in a thread and asyncio does not work well within a thread, we now use the threading implementation.

title: [Core] Logging buffered for run section
body:
When running the following yaml file, the `hi2` and `hi3` will only be printed after the `sleep` is finished. It can cause trouble for spot jobs debugging as the preemption can cause the latest log not showing up.
```
run: |
  echo hi
  echo hi2
  echo hi3
  sleep 12000
  echo bye
```
